awd_titl_txt: Digitization,Transcription, and Publication of Sauk Narratives
awd_abstract_narration:
Data from languages spoken by smaller communities worldwide have been shown to have important implications for theories of language change and for discovering the limits and possible diversity of linguistic structure.  For this reason, the Documenting Endangered Languages program supports projects that make available high-quality data from the approximately 40% of the world's languages that may have no remaining speakers in the next fifty years.

There is utmost urgency in documenting Sauk, a highly complex Native American language of the Algonquian family, with only a few remaining fluent speakers, all over the age of 80.  Jacob Manatowa-Bailey of the Sac and Fox Nation of Oklahoma will increase documentation of Sauk language and culture through curation of rare recordings by some of the last speakers who were raised in monolingual Sauk households, Guy Wakolee, Carl Butler, Dewey Butler, and Grace Masquas.  The recordings include personal stories of growing up in traditional Sauk homes during the 1920's and 1930's, a story of the Sauk migration to Oklahoma, descriptions of traditional practices such as procedures for building houses, and other remembrances of the knowledge, values, and customs of the speakers' parents and grandparents.

Manatowa-Bailey will digitize, transcribe, and disseminate this extraordinary collection which will be of immediate use to linguists working on the reconstruction of Algonquian and to those interested in linguistic typology.  The digital audio and video files, fully transcribed, will also be valuable tools in the continuation of Sauk language revitalization efforts, used in the development of fluency development, language instruction, and embedded readings.

Results of this project will be archived at the Sam Noble Museum and the Sam Noble Museum and the Sac and Fox Nation Cultural Archives.

por.por_cntn:
The primary aim of this project was to preserve and develop historical recordings of first-language speakers of Sauk, a highly endangered Algonquian language spoken in central Oklahoma. The contents of these recordings include interviews, oral histories, and narratives told by members of the last generation of individuals raised in Sauk-speaking households. This collection represents a significant portion of the recordings of spoken Sauk with the last first-language speakers, and includes topics such as personal narratives about growing up in traditional Sauk homes during the 1920s and 1930s, an account of the Sauk migration to Oklahoma, and descriptions of traditional Sauk practices and values.

Through this project, our team assembled and digitized a total of 57 recordings, comprising approximately 24 hours of Sauk narrative. This project adopted a combination of oral and written annotation methods to develop these materials. Time-aligned written Sauk transcriptions and English translations were created for approximately 10.5 hours of this corpus. Working with the remaining two first-language speakers of Sauk, oral annotations have been provided for over five hours of the historical source recordings. This project has also resulted in the creation of detailed catalogue information for these recordings and a searchable lexical database. Together, these outputs significantly advance the current state of documentation for Sauk, serving as a basis for further linguistic analysis and supporting community language revitalization efforts.

This project also provided opportunities for Sauk tribal members to develop capacity in current language documentation methods and practices, particularly in the areas of digitization and annotation. A major focus of the project was on providing in-community training to Sauk language learners and second-language speakers, who then contributed to the annotation of these recordings. Participation in the annotation process provided learners with exposure to naturalistic spoken Sauk that can be particularly difficult to gain in a context of advanced language endangerment, helping to advance their proficiency while also contributing to corpus development. These combined experiences will likely have an impact on the future language teaching practices of these individuals, as well as on their future documentation work with Elders.
